p.s: The novel The Tortilla Curtain, written by T. C. Boyle and published in 1995, deals with the harsh reality of undocumented immigrants, who are seeking a better live in the United States.
The passage at hand is an excerpt from Part Twopart two, Chapterchapter 6 of the novel.
It depictesdepicts the growing paranoia of Delaney Mossbacher, which is fueled by his prejudice against Mexicans.

one of the protagonists of the story, is talking to one of his neighbours, Todd Sweet, about the ongoing discussion wetherwhether Arroyo Blanco, the wealthy area they live in, should become a gated community.

The majority of the inhabitants of the area voted for the erection of the gate, while Delaney, in that part, is still against it, because he sees it as undemocratic and exlusionary and he wants to convince his wife Kyra and his good friend Jack Jardine from his point of view.
But during the conversation with Todd Sweet, he suddenly spots José Navidad.
He is an undocumented immigrant from Mexico and also involved in criminal activities.
Delaney has seen and heard of multiple occasions, for example on the day his car was stolen or when his wife tells him that José was roumingroaming around their house.
Delaney confronts him on the lawn of one of his other neighbourneighbours, Jack Cherrystone, who is out of town.
He tells José to leave, who does not comply, which makes Delaney feel humiliated by José's indifferent reaction.
This is where Delaney grabs him by the arm, but José quickly reacts and spits at him.
Delaney becomes more and more agitated, because he assumes he will havea to fight José till death.
But José pulls out flyers he claims to distribute throughout the neighbourhood, which are informing the residantsresidents of Arroyo Blanco about further discurse of the gated community topic.
After that José leaves and Delaney feels ashamed of his irrational behaviour.
